title-group.article-title: An investigation on new high performance Schiff base polyurethanes

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemistry, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan
2Department of Physics, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, Islamabad, Pakistan

author-notes.corresp: Muhammad Ilyas Sarwar, Department of Chemistry, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad- 45320, Pakistan Email: ilyassarwar@hotmail.com

abstract.p: Novel poly(urethane-azomethine-thiourea)s (PUATs) were synthesized via one-step polymerization from newly prepared diol chain extender (1,4-phenylene bis((E)-1-(4-hydroxobenzylidene)thiourea) (PBHBT)), containing C=S and –C=N– linkages, along with 1,4-phenylene diisocyanate (PDI) as hard segments and 20, 40 and 60 mol.% polyethylene glycol (PEG) forming soft segments. The prepared chain extender and polymers were characterized via elemental, Fourier transform infrared, 1H- and 13C-NMR analyses, and physical properties such as η inh, solubility, crystallinity, flame retardancy and thermal stability were studied. According to X-ray diffraction patterns, the Schiff base polymers exhibited amorphous morphologies and their molar masses were in the range of 148 × 103–163 × 103 g mol−1. Thermogravimetric analysis indicated that PUATs with 20 and 40 mol.% PEG were fairly stable above 500°C having T 10 of 511–527°C and had high glass transition temperatures about 249–251°C. In comparison with typical polyurethanes, PUATs with lower polyol content exhibited better non-inflammability, T g values, chemical and thermal stability owing to rigid hard segment structure.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Recently, polyurethanes have established an increasingly exceptional position among the significant organic polymers for their intensive technological applications, 1 biomaterials in implants, 2,3 and engineering materials, 4 along with electronic and coating industries. 5 This broad spectrum of relevance is closely connected to the surplus of physical forms that these materials can assume such as elastomers, 6,7 rigid and flexible forms 8,9 and adherent films and powders. 10 This is possible because of the inherent higher mechanical strength, excellent abrasion resistance, ease in processing and biocompatibility of polyurethanes. Over the last 20 years, thermoplastic polyurethanes have acquired plenty of traction in the market place due to their versatility. Thermoplastic polyurethane elastomers are segmented block copolymers comprising an alternating sequence of hard and soft segments. The hard segment is formed by extending a terminal diisocyanate with a low molecular weight diol or with a low molecular weight diamine. As a result of the incompatibility between the hard and soft segments, polyurethane undergoes microphase separation. The primary driving force for domain formation arises from the intermolecular hydrogen bonding between hard segments. The hard segments (composed of diisocyanates and short-chain diol or diamine chain extenders) particularly affect the modulus, hardness, tear strength and high-temperature resistance while the soft segments (formed by long-chain diols) control flexibility and softness. 11 Considerable research has been carried out on these polyurethane materials including various efforts interpreting the effect of chain extenders, soft and hard segments, 12
–17 degradation and stability 18,19 and other properties. 20,21 However, thermoplastic polyurethanes have certain limitations like inadequate thermal stability and flame retardancy which restrict its end use in certain areas, especially in aerospace applications. There are numerous compositional variations that can be employed in the preparation of polyurethanes having diverse physical and chemical properties. As the characteristic properties of polyurethane depend on its chemical structure and the ‘superstructure’ originated from hydrogen bonding. The superstructure of polyurethanes strongly depends on the molecular weight of the soft segment, hard segment content, preparation conditions and chemical structure of the raw materials. Both aliphatic and aromatic isocyanates can be used to synthesize polyurethanes. Aromatic isocyanate-based polyurethanes generally endure superior mechanical properties because of the strong cohesive forces between the hard segments. In general, presence of an aromatic isocyanate in the hard segment produces a stiffer polymer chain with higher melting point. The most commonly used isocyanates in polyurethane synthesis are aromatic isocyanates, such as toluene diisocyanate (TDI) and methylene bis (p-phenyl) isocyanate (MDI). These isocyanates can result in high performance polyurethane elastomers via cautious selection of chain extenders and polyol backbones. Other aromatic isocyanates such as naphthalene diisocyanate (NDI) and 3,3′-bitoluene diisocyanate (TODI) can also produce high performance polymers, but at a higher cost than MDI and TDI-based elastomers.

The properties of polyurethanes can easily be tailored by controlled alterations in polyol chain length as well as by varying the proportions and chemical nature of the constituents which make up the flexible and rigid segments of the polymer chain. Earlier, the present authors developed poly(azomethine-imide)s with C=S units. 22,23 that were soluble in common organic solvents. As a continuation of those studies, herein the preparation and characterization of new type of poly(urethane-azomethine-thiourea)s (PUATs), based on synthesized diol chain extender (1,4-phenylene bis((E)-1-(4-hydroxobenzylidene)thiourea) (PBHBT)), containing thiourea and azomethine groups, and 1,4-phenylene diisocyanate (PDI) as hard segments is presented. Polyethylene glycol (PEG) (20, 40, 60 mol.%) with molar mass 2000 g mol−1 were used in the preparation of these PUATs as soft segments. Usually Schiff base polymers 24 exhibit interesting base properties because of the presence of –C=N– linkages. Polymeric/azo materials have been paid immense attention in past decades owing to their environmental stability and huge potential applications in high-technology fields, such as waveguide switches, photomechanical systems, data manipulation, nonlinear optical materials, holographic memories as well as mechanical properties. 25
–28 Furthermore, aromatic polyazomethines are generally insoluble in common organic solvents and precipitate from the reaction medium before high molecular weights are obtained. Eventually, the authors’ interest in processable segmented polyurethanes with good retention of chemical, thermal and non-inflammable properties for industrial applications has led to the examination of 1,4-phenylene bis((E)-1-(4-hydroxobenzylidene)thiourea) (PBHBT) and PEG-based polyurethanes. In this effort the unique combination of urethane, azomethine, and thiourea functionalities imparted sole features to the new polymers owing to their cumulative effects. The presence of thiourea moieties improved the solubility of high molecular weight Schiff-base polyurethanes having large amount of hard segment content. Moreover, the azomethine/thiourea-based polyurethanes revealed superior thermal stability and flame retardancy.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Polyethylene glycol (PEG-2000) (molecular weight of 2000 g mol−1), N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) (99%), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (99%) and chloroform (99%) were procured from Merck. 1,4-Phenylene diisocyanate (PDI) (99%), 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde (98%), N, N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) (99%), xylene (99%) and toluene (99.8%) were provided by Aldrich. Ammonium thiocyanate (98%), dimethylformamide (DMF) (99%) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) (99.5%) were supplied by Fluka.

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer was used for the elemental analysis. A Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer, Model No. FTSW 300 MX, manufactured by BIO-RAD (4 cm−1 resolution) was used for recording IR spectra. NMR spectra were recorded at room temperature using a BRUKER spectrometer operating at 300.13 MHz for 1H- and at 75.47 MHz for 13C-NMR. The solvent used for analysis was deutrated dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO-d 6). Inherent viscosity (η inh) was measured in DMF at 30°C with an Ubbelohde viscometer on 0.5 g dL−1 polymer solutions. The weight-average molecular weight (M w) was calculated through GPC using DMF as an eluent and refractive index (RI) detector. Thermal stability of the polymers was verified by a METTLER TOLEDO TGA/SDTA 851e thermo gravimetric analyzer using 1–5 mg of the sample in an Al2O3 crucible at a heating rate of 10°C min−1. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed by METTLER TOLEDO DSC 822e differential scanning calorimeter taking 5–10 mg of samples in aluminum pans and heated at a rate of 10°C min−1. An X-ray diffractometer (3040/60 X’pert PRO) with Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 30 mA) was used to obtain X-ray diffractrograms of polymers at room temperature. In order to study the chemical resistance of polyurethanes, various chemicals were used. Teflon petri dishes coated with films of the polyurethanes (63 ± 5 µm thickness) were kept in 250 mL beakers containing 150 mL of various chemical media at ambient temperature (30 ± 2°C) for 7 days. Stanton Redcroft FTA Flammability Unit (nitrogen gas, oxygen gas and precision pressure regulator systems) was used to find out the limiting oxygen index (LOI) of PUATs. LOI were measured according to ASTM D 2863, which is a method to determine the minimum concentration of oxygen in an oxygen/nitrogen mixture that will support a flaming burn in a specimen.

sec.title: Synthesis of 1,4-phenylene bis((E)-1-(4-hydroxobenzylidene)thiourea)
sec.p: Synthesis of PBHBT involved the preparation of 1,4-phenylene bis(thiourea) from 1,4-phenylenediamine and then its condensation with 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde. 1,4-Phenylenediamine (0.2 mol), 16 mL of conc. HCl, ammonium thiocyanate (0.2 mol) and 120 mL of deaerated water were exhaustively mixed and heated in a porcelain dish for 2 h (on a steam bath). The reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature and then again evaporated to dryness for 6–7 h. Consequently, the product obtained was boiled with a small quantity of charcoal in ethanol, filtered and cooled. 1,4-Phenylene bis(thiourea) 23 thus obtained was recrystallized from ethanol and dried under reduced pressure at 85°C for 36 h. Afterwards, 1,4-phenylene bis(thiourea) (0.1 mol), 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde (0.2 mol) and 130 mL of absolute alcohol were agitated in a Dean-Stark apparatus for 0.5 h at room temperature. After the removal of azeotropic mixture at 100°C, the reaction mixture was further refluxed for 2.5 h. Then it was cooled to collect the solid, followed by washing with dilute HCl and hot water. Ultimately, the product obtained by recrystallization from C2H5OH was dried under reduced pressure at 80°C for 36 h to afford PBHBT with 96% yield. Elemental analysis for C22H18N4O2S2: Calculated = % C 60.81, % H 4.18, % N 12.89; Found = % C 60.11, % H 4.08, % N 12.80. FTIR (KBr) (Figure 1): 3485 cm−1 (–OH), 3363 and 1597 cm−1 (sec. amine N–H stretch and bend), 3042 cm−1 (aromatic C–H stretch), 1611 cm−1 (–C=N– stretch), 1153 cm−1 (C=S stretch).1H-NMR (300.13 MHz, DMSO-d 6, δ ppm) presented in Figure 2: 5.10 (s, 2H, Ha), 6.82 (d, 4H, Hb), 7.41 (d, 4H, Hc), 8.12 (s, 2H, Hd), 9.41 (s, 2H, He), 6.21 (s, 4H, Hf). 13C-NMR (75.47 MHz, DMSO-d 6, δ ppm) specified in Figure 3: 160.3 (C1), 116.0 (C2), 130.6 (C3), 125.2 (C4), 163.7 (C5), thiocarbonyl C=S 183.1 (C6), 133.2 (C7), 127.1 (C8).

sec.title: Synthesis of segmented PUATs (one-step procedure)
sec.p: PUATs were prepared via single-step procedure 29 employing PDI; PBHBT and 20, 40 and 60 mol.% PEG at the molar ratio of NCO/OH = 1. HO-terminated soft segment (PEG) was degassed and dried in a 500 mL three-necked reaction kettle equipped with magnetic stirrer, reflux condenser, dropping funnel, thermometer and N2 inlet under high vacuum (20 Pa) at 100°C for 1 h. After cooling to 45°C, a solution of chain extender (PBHBT) in DMF was charged into the above flask. Later, PDI was also added into the flask keeping a molar ratio of 1 : 1 (NCO/OH). The mixture was rigorously agitated under N2 atmosphere for 7 h at 0–3°C using an ice-water bath. After that, the above mixture was heated to 120°C for 24 h and the resultant solution was viscous but transparent. Finally, PUAT precursor solution was concentrated, dissolved in toluene, precipitated in petroleum ether and dried in vacuum at 80°C for 12 h. Spectral data of PUATs corroborated the structures of the synthesized polymers (Figure 4). FTIR (KBr): displayed peaks at 3318 cm−1 (N–H stretch), 3079 cm−1 (aromatic C–H stretch), 2951 cm−1 (aliphatic C–H stretch), 1595 cm−1 (N–H bend), 1721 cm−1 (C=O stretch), 1241 cm−1 (C–O stretch), 1155 cm−1 (C=S stretch). 1H-NMR (300.13 MHz, DMSO-d 6, δ ppm) of PUAT 1 (Figure 5): 7.27 (s, Ha), 9.59 (s, Hb, –OCONH–), 7.48 (d, Hc), 6.81 (d, Hd), 8.12 (s, He), 9.37 (s, Hf), 6.21 (s, Hg), 3.09–3.54 (aliphatic H, polyol).

sec.title: Film casting
sec.p: Films of PUATs were also prepared in order to study the chemical resistance in different media. A thin transparent layer of solution in each case was spread on a Teflon mold and heated to 80°C for 12 h. These thin films were then exposed to different media (aqueous, acidic and basic) for any observed change in their texture and integrity.

sec.title: Synthesis of monomers and polymers
sec.p: At present, novel poly(urethane-azomethine-thiourea)s were synthesized by the condensation of newly prepared chain extender, PBHBT, and polyol with aromatic diisocyanate. Firstly, the synthesis of diol compound (Scheme 1) was accomplished using 1,4-phenylene bis(thiourea) and 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde (1:2). Subsequently, novel diol was exploited as chain extender for the fabrication of PUATs. Each of the PDI-based thermoplastic segmented PUATs was prepared, according to Scheme 2, from PBHBT chain extenders and varying mol.% of PEG as a soft segment, at the molar ratio of NCO/OH = 1. Despite the apparent simplicity of this synthesis, any alterations in the soft and hard segment ratio caused considerable changes in polymer chains stacking, leading to enhancement in thermal properties of the material. The structure of the new diol, PBHBT, was established by elemental analysis, FTIR, 1H- and 13C-NMR spectral data. The synthesized PUATs were characterized by spectroscopic analysis, viscometry, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), limiting oxygen index (LOI) measurements, gel permeation chromatography (GPC) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) techniques. Two of the synthesized polymers, PUAT 1 derived from PBHBT, PDI and 20 mol.% PEG and PUAT 2 derived from PBHBT, PDI and 40 mol.% PEG, exhibited fairly high thermal stability and flame retardancy. In this manner, excellent thermal and flame-resistant properties owing to lowering the soft segment content resulted in a significant increase in heat/flame stability. Furthermore, the values of η inh and GPC data specified high molecular weights of these polymers. Presently the main structural modification of PUATs was the introduction of thiourea and azomethine linkages in polyurethane hard segments to augment their solubility while preserving heat stability.

caption.p: Scheme for the synthesis of PBHBT.
Scheme for the synthesis of PUATs.

sec.title: Organosolubility
sec.p: One of the objectives of this study was to produce modified polyurethanes with improved solubility. Solubility of azomethine-thiourea based polyurethanes was tested in various polar aprotic and less polar solvents as shown in Table 1. Accordingly, the solubility of polymers was clearly dependent on PEG soft-segment content used. PUAT 1 obtained from 20 mol.% PEG exhibited good solubility in polar solvents such as NMP, DMAc, DMF and DMSO but insoluble in THF, CHCl3, xylene, toluene, methanol and water. On the other hand, the polymers obtained from PBHBT, PDI and the higher PEG content were not only soluble in polar aprotic solvents but also in chlorinated and polar solvents such as chloroform and THF. However, the rate of dissolution of polyurethanes depends on the concentration of polyol soft structure, as PUAT 3 based on 60 mol.% PEG showed better solubility in comparison with other polyurethanes. It took up to 30 min for complete dissolution of PUAT 3 sample in less effective solvents such as CHCl3 and THF, whereas PUAT 2 required heating for complete solubility in these solvents. Therefore, increasing the PEG content enhanced the rate of dissolving of polyurethanes. The solubility data confirmed that co-occurrence of packing disruptive C=S units in hard segments preserved good solubility of polyurethanes in common organic solvents. Consequently, it is possible to increase azomethine and thiourea-based hard structure content, –PDI–PBHBT–, in polyurethanes without sacrificing their solubility and processability. In general, novel poly(urethane-azomethine-thiourea)s presented excellent solubility when compared with several reported Schiff-base polyurethanes. 30,31

fn.p: a Solubility: ++, soluble at room temperature; +–, partially soluble at room temperature; +h, soluble on heating; –, insoluble.

sec.title: Molecular weight analysis
sec.p: Inherent viscosity (η inh) of PUATs measured in DMF solvent at 30°C was in the range of 1.66–1.69 dL g−1. This viscosity data of polymer solution is a measure of molecular weight, thus the polymers exhibited high molecular weights. A relationship between the PEG content of polyurethanes and η inh was also observed. Data further revealed that η inh decreased with increasing mol.% of polyol in the polymer, but this decrease was less pronounced as compared to the previously reported polyurethanes by Liu, 32 in which η inh decreased markedly as the polyol content increased. So, overall PUATs exhibited much higher η inh relative to previously synthesized azomethine polyurethanes. 33 GPC measurements were also carried out for the molar mass determination (Table 2) of PUATs and the results revealed that polymers had high molar masses. Thus PUAT 1 with high content of hard structure exhibited higher M w of 163 × 103 g mol−1.

caption.p: η inh, M w, polydispersity and % yield of PUATs.

sec.title: Thermal analysis
sec.p: Weight-loss data of PUATs obtained through TGA (Table 3 and Figure 6) suggested that PUAT 1 and 2 with 20 and 40 mol.% PEG, respectively, exhibited higher thermal stability relative to PUAT 3 with 60 mol.% PEG. Thermograms of these poly(urethane-azomethine-thiourea)s showed two-stage decomposition. Initial decomposition (T 0) of PUAT 1 prepared from 20 mol.% PEG was 517°C, decomposition temperature at 10% gravimetric loss (T 10) was 527°C and the decomposition extended up to 574°C. Similarly PBHBT, PDI and PEG (40 mol.%)-based PUAT 2 also showed high stability; T 0 of 501°C and T 10 up to 511°C. These curves showed a major weight loss between 500 and 590°C, while char yields were around 58 and 50% at 600°C for PUAT 1 and 2, respectively. This slight variation in weight loss of PUAT 1 and 2 was due to the difference in hard segments content. Furthermore, TGA data clearly indicated that 60 mol.% polyol-based PUAT 3 exhibited worst thermal stability than polyurethanes containing lower polyol content. In addition, lower char yield of polyurethane with 60 mol.% PEG (29%) was indicative of poor thermal stability. To study the effect of hard segment content on the stability of PUATs, glass-transition temperatures (T g) were also monitored (Figure 7). No transitions related to softening or melting was detected, although glass transitions (T g) were observed in the thermograms. PUAT 1 and PUAT 2, with 20 and 40 mol.% soft segments, showed higher T g values of 251 and 259°C, respectively. As increased hard segment content, –PDI–PBHBT–, in polyurethanes enhanced the polymer chain rigidity and thus confirmed their segmental motion. Finally, new segmented PUATs based on new thiourea- and azomethine-derivative diols exhibited much higher thermal stability compared with previously prepared polyurethanes containing azomethine linkages in the main chains. 34 –36

caption.p: TGA curves of PUATs at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 in N2
DSC thermograms of PUATs at heating rate of 10°C min−1 in N2
Thermal analyses data of different PUATs.

fn.p: T g, glass transition temperature; T 0, decomposition temperature; T 10, temperature for 10% weight loss; T max, maximum decomposition temperature; Y c, char yield; weight of polymer remaining; LOI, limiting oxygen index.

sec.title: Flame retardancy
sec.p: Flame retardancy of the polymers was investigated by measuring their LOI values as shown in Table 3. The polymers exhibited LOI values in the range of 33–41, and therefore, the materials do not burn in atmosphere. The presence of higher hard segment content in polymers showed influence on LOI values. In comparison between the polymers obtained from the same chain extender and polyol, it was found that LOI values decreased with the increasing mol.% of PEG. Also the new polyurethanes are more non-inflammable relative to previous flame retardant Schiff-base polyurethanes. 37

sec.title: XRD analysis
sec.p: XRD patterns of PUATs are presented in Figure 8. All poly(urethane-azomethine-thiourea)s exhibited amorphous domains. This amorphous/non-crystalline nature of polyurethanes is in agreement with the above-presented DSC data as no endotherms were observed for these polyurethanes.

sec.title: Chemical resistance of poly(urethane-azomethine-thiourea)s
sec.p: Chemical resistance tests of PUATs (by visual evaluation of any change in the film integrity) were performed in acidic, basic as well as aqueous media. The polyurethanes were resistant in acidic media (20 wt.% aqueous H2SO4 and 37 wt.% aqueous HCl), basic media (40 wt.% aqueous NaOH), in 23 wt.% aqueous NaCl and also in distilled water (Table 4). PUAT 1 and 2 samples were chemically resistant and there was no effect on their surface after finishing the test period. However, PUAT 3 (with 60 mol.% hard segments) degraded completely in aqueous H2SO4 and HCl media. Apparently, the presence of a greater hard segments content in PUAT 1 and 2 (20 and 40 mol.%, respectively) led to enhanced interchain interactions in polyurethanes, hence increasing their resistance to acidic media. The PUAT 3 sample also underwent swelling and deterioration in basic medium. The excellent solvent resistance of PUAT 1 and 2 films, compared with reported polymers, 38 is considered to be caused by the formation of homogeneously arranged hydrogen-bonded urethane structure.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article reports on the synthesis and characterization of novel type of Schiff-base polyurethanes based on 20, 40 and 60 mol.% polyol, short chain diol and PDI. The effect of the newly synthesized diol chain extender (PBHBT) and different mol.% of polyol used on the structure as well as some physical properties such as solution viscosity, molecular weight, solubility, heat stability and flame retardancy of poly(urethane-azomethine-thiourea)s were studied. The resulting processable, heat and flame-resistant segmented polyurethanes possessed high molecular weight as obtained from the condensation of short chain diol bearing C=S and –C=N– linkages, PDI, and PEG (soft segment) at the molar ratio of NCO/OH = 1. The synthesized polymers possessed amorphous structures. Thermal stability and non-inflammability of poly(urethane-thiourea)s was found to increase by lowering the soft segment content and the introduction of PBHBT chain extenders in hard segments of PDI-based polyurethanes. Hence, the new diol, PBHBT, can be considered as a candidate for the fabrication of polyurethanes that are able to exhibit some interesting and potentially useful characteristics having enormous technical and economic importance. The results indicated that high-temperature resistant azomethine-based segmented polyurethanes could be used in the design of high-performance thermo-optic 39 polymer devices.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: A.K. expresses thanks to Higher Education Commission of Pakistan (HEC) for pecuniary support in this work under International Research Support Initiative Program (IRSIP) and Indigenous 5000 Ph.D Fellowship Scheme Batch-III (063-111354-Ps3-068).
